sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: StarDict is a Cross-Platform and international dictionary written in Gtk2. It has powerful features such as "Glob-style pattern matching," "Scan selected word," "Fuzzy query," etc.

sect2.title: Starting &app;
sect2.para: You can start &app; in the following ways:

listitem.para: Choose AccessoriesStarDict.
Type stardict, then press Return.
You can specify a word to query too :
or a Glob-style pattern matching string :
or do a fuzzy query :

note.para: If &app; is already running, it will perform the query in the existing StarDict window.

sect2.title: When You Start &app;
sect2.para: When you start &app;, the following window is displayed.

textobject.phrase: Shows &app; main window. Contains Search input combo, Tool buttons, Word list, Definition area and Setting buttons.

sect2.para: The &app; main window consists of the following elements:

listitem.para: Use this field to enter the word that you want to look up. You can also access recently-queried words through the dropdown box.
You can click these buttons to do fuzzy quering, look up the previously queried word, look up the next and previous words from the list on the left, and pop up the main menu.
Shows the words that have been found in this search.
&app; displays the definition of a word in this area of the window.

The bottom-left of the window contains the Scan selection check button, the Info button and the Quit button. Checking the Scan selection check button will cause &app; to automatically look up words that you highlight in any application. The bottom-right of the window contains the Internet search button, the StarDict project website button, the Dictionary management button and the Preferences button.

sect2.title: Notification area icon
sect2.para: &app; will also add an icon to the notification area. When you iconify the main window, the window will be hiden. After you click the icon, the window will be shown again. If you right click this icon, it will popup a menu where you can choose to toggle Scan selection, or to Quit. You can toggle Scan selection directly by ctrl-clicking the icon. Clicking the middle mouse button on the icon will query the selected word.

sect2.title: Scan selection
sect2.para: &app; can automatically scan selections. This means that when you select a word or phrase in &app; or in any other application, &app; will get the text that you selected and search for it, then display a floating window containing the result of the search.

In Windows the scan mode works differently. It has nothing to do with selection in fact. &app; extracts the text under the pointer when you pause the mouse for a while. Normally &app; looks up a space-separated word under the pointer, if the pointer is over a blank, then two space-separated words are used, the one to the left and the one to the right of the blank. If the word or the word pair is not found, &app; proceeds looking up words consisting of only capitals or of only lower case letters and do some other tricks in order to extract the word to translate. You may help &app; to extract the right word or a part of a word selecting it. Although &app; does not work with selections, selection may effect the text &app; extracts.

Scanning in Windows may not work with some applications. For example, it's known that scanning does not work with FireFox 3.x and Windows Console (cmd.exe process). The scanning feature depends on the way application outputs text. If scanning does not work, you may harness another &app; feature — Clipboard scanning, see .

textobject.phrase: Shows &app; floating window. Contains Tool buttons and Definition area.

listitem.para: You may drag the window to move it.
The floating window will disappear when you move your pointer some distance away.
You may configure &app; so it will do scanning only when a special modifier key is held down.
You may switch scan mode on and off by pressing the CtrlAltx shortcut.

&app; remembers the last text looked up in the floating window and will not lookup it again. If you need to see the translation again, you should lookup another word first (it's not enough to simply change selection) and then lookup the original word. Another possibility is to middle-click on the notification area icon, &app; will lookup the selection unconditionally.

sect2.para: The &app; floating window consists of the following elements:

listitem.para: The buttons will be hidden automatically to save display space. When your mouse pointer enters the floating window, the buttons will appear immediately, and disappear again as the mouse pointer leaves.

You can click these buttons to query a word in the main window, copy the query result to clipboard, pronounce the word, stop selection scanning, etc. To the far right is the Lock floating window button. If the floating window is locked, it will always be shown there.
The query result is displayed in this area.

sect2.title: Looking Up a Word
sect2.para: To look up the definition of a word, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Type the word that you want to look up in the Search combo box.
&app; will show the definition immediately. If not found, you can press Return to do a fuzzy query or just click the Fuzzy query button.
Use the scrollbar to scroll through the definition. Select the words in the word list to view the related words.

sect2.title: Clearing the Display Area
sect2.para: To clear the text of the Search input combo, click the Clear button on the left, or just press Alt-C or ESC.

sect2.title: To Copy Text to Another Application
sect2.para: There are two ways to copy the text in the display area to another application:

listitem.para: To copy all of the text, click the Copy button by the top of the Definition area.
To copy some of the text, select the text that you want to copy, then click your mouse's right button and choose Copy.

sect2.title: To Find Text in the Display Area
sect2.para: To find text in the display area, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: click the Find button by the top of the Definition area.
Type the string that you want to find in the Find text box, then press Return. You cannot use wildcards.
To find the next occurrence of the word, press Return again.

sect2.title: Toggle scan mode
sect2.para: There are a number of ways to enable or disable the scan selection mode. When in scan mode, &app; shows translation of the text you select in different windows.

itemizedlist.title: Ways to enable the scan mode

listitem.para: Toggle a checkbox at the bottom left corner of the &app; main window.
Right-click the notification area icon and check Scan in the pop-up menu.
Use CtrlAltx shortcut (it toggles scan mode). See .

sect2.title: Definition area toolbar
sect2.para: The difinition area toolbar is at the top of the Definition aria. It contains a number of buttons. We describe them in left-to-right order.

listitem.para: Hide or show the word list to the left.
Copy definition area text into clipboard.

This is a button with an additional dropdown menu. Clicking the button you make &app; pronounce the current word using the first TTS engine that can do it. The dropdown menu allows you to select the TTS engine to use.
This engine use sound samples performed by real people.
Espeak TTS plugin.
Festival TTS plugin.
TTS command you may specify in the Preferences dialog. See .
Depending on cofiguration settings, installed plugins and other factors, the list of TTS engines may be shorter.

Save definition text into a file. The new text is appended to the end of the file. The file to use is specified in the section of the Preferences dialog. You may also specify to export only the found word, not its definition. &app; exports not the word you searched for but the word that was found, the one which translation is shown in the definition area. When "export only word" is not specified, selection is taken into account. When text is selected in the definition aria, the selected text is exported prepended with the found word. When there are no selected text, all text of the definition area is exported.
Hotkey: Alte
Search for text in the definition area. This button opens a search bar at the bottom of the definition area where you may type a word to search.
Hotkey: Ctrlf
Quit &app;.
Minimize to tray. &app; main window is closed, taskbar item disappears, but the application continues to run. You may open the main window again clicking on the notification area icon.
Iconify the application. The main window is hidden, the taskbar item remains.
Save word definition to a file. See for more details.
Show help.
Search in the definition text. See for more details.
Go Back. Return to the word that was queried before.
Previous word. Query the previous word in the index.
Next word. Query the next word in the index.
Menu. Show the main menu.
Query clipboard text in &app;.
Clear the search field and focus it.
The focus is in the index window.
If the selected index item has children, expand or collapse the item. If the selected index item has no children, query the item in the main window.
The focus is in the definition area.
Requery the text in the search field.
Focus the search field.
Clear the search field and focus it.

Open the main window of &app;. The main window may be iconified, or &app; may only exist as a notification area icon. In all the cases pressing this hotkey presents the main window to the user. You may change the hotkey in the Preferences dialog, see .
Toggle scan mode. You may change the hotkey in the Preferences dialog, see .

sect1.title: Preferences
sect1.para: To configure &app;, click the Preferences button at the right-bottom corner of the main window or click the Main menu button and choose Preferences.

term.guilabel: Only scan while modifier key is being pressed.

listitem.para: Only do scanning while the modifier key being pressed. The modifier key is set by .
Default: FALSE.

term.guilabel: Hide floating window when modifier key released.

listitem.para: When this option is set, the floating window is hidden when user releases the modifier key. Note: the window is hidden only if the pointer has the same position it had when the window was shown. In addition to hiding the window, the last selected text is forgotten, which allow you to lookup the same text again simply pressing the modifier key. When this option is not set, releasing the modifier key has no effect on the floating window.
This option has effect only if is checked.
Default: TRUE.
This option allows to choose a modifier keys or a key combination that enables scanning.
This option has effect only if is checked.
Default key: Win (depends on configuration).
Enables clipboard scanning. If enabled, when new text is copied into the clipboard, &app; lookup the text into the floating window.
This option is only available in &winedition; of &app;.
Default: FALSE.

The scan mode shortcut enables or disables the scan mode. Check the Use scan hotkey checkbox to enable this shortcut. You may change the shortcut in the field to the right of the label. Click inside the field and press the key combination you want to assign to this action.
Default: TRUE
Default shortcut: CtrlAltx.
Allows you to override the system's default font when running &app;. If this option is turned on, then the font named in the "Custom Font" option will be used instead of the system font.
Font settings apply immediately.
Default: FALSE.

term.guilabel: Create cache files to speed up loading.

listitem.para: Opening a dictionary the first time, &app; does some calculations to access dictionary contents speedily. &app; may save the results in special cache files that will be used the next time &app; starts. With cache files &app; starts quicker, since it does not need to do the same calculations again. It's highly recommended to enable caching. In the first place, &app; tries to save a cache file along with the dictionary. If it fails, for example, because the directory is write-protected, &app; creates a file in the user home directory, in &app;'s directory.
Default: TRUE.

term.guilabel: Sort word list by collation function.

listitem.para: Normally, &app; uses an index of words to look up a word in a dictionary. When the word is present in the index, the corresponding article is shown. Otherwise adjacent words will be checked and may be used as result. &app; uses heuristic algorithms to decide whether the particular word may be suggested as result of the search or not. The order of words in an index is very important and it would be handy if index items were sorted by alphabet or according to other rules. Collation functions allows you to specify a number of predefined sorting orders, that may be helpful when working with particular languages.

To use a collation function check the Sort word list by collation function checkbox and select the desired function from the Collation function list. The collation function will be applied as soon as you close the Preferences dialog. It may take a considerable amount of time to apply the new collation function, please, be patient.

It's highly recommended to enable the
option, otherwise &app; will do sorting each time the application starts.
Default: FALSE.
Remove all &app; cache files.

sect3.title: Export
sect3.para: &app; may export search results into a file. You have two options: export only the found word or export the entire search result, the word article.

listitem.para: When this option is set, &app; exports only the found word, otherwise exports the complete article.
Default: TRUE.
Name of the file where to export data.

sect3.title: Sound
sect3.para: There are a number of cases when &app; needs to play sound files. &app; may accompany GUI actions with sounds. &app; may pronounce the words you search in the dictionary. Some articles may contain linked sound files you can play.
To play sound files &app; may harness platform-specific services or use commands you specify on this page.
This page allows to configure some aspects of the TTS subsystem. The TTS subsystem is used to pronounce words by computer.

listitem.para: Whether enable sound event. &app; will play sound event when button is active, released, and when pop up menu.
Default: TRUE.

Specifies a command for playing sound files. You may specify a program name (with or without full path) accompaned with any options required. The file name to play will be appended to this command at run time.

On some platforms &app; use platform-specific services to play sound files first, then retreat to the custom command provided by the user if the service is unable to play the file. You may specify to always use the custom command selecting this option.
Default: FALSE.

Allows to specify locations of RealPeopleTTS bundles. RealPeopleTTS bundle is a collection of sound files containing speech samples performed by real people. Normally, one file contains one recoded word, the file is named after that word. Sound files are organized into a number of directories. In the text field you must specify a path to the top level directory of the bundle. The order of paths in the text field is important. &app; checks directories from top to bottom, the first found file will be used.
C:\Program Files\WyabdcRealPeopleTTS, C:\Program Files\OtdRealPeopleTTS, WyabdcRealPeopleTTS, OtdRealPeopleTTS
/usr/share/WyabdcRealPeopleTTS, /usr/share/OtdRealPeopleTTS
Allows to use the command below to read words. You need to restart &app; for changes to take effect.
Default: FALSE.

This field allows to specify a command to use to pronounce words. You need to provide a print-like string, with "%s" specifing the place where the word (or phrase) to pronounce will be inserted. You need to restart &app; for changes to take effect. Do not forget to check the checkbox above if you want to use this command.
Default: nothing.

Specifies a command for playing video files. You may specify a program name (with or without full path) accompaned with any options required. The file name to play will be appended to this command at run time. Video files may be linked with dictionary articles.
Whether to highlight the search term in the definition area. A search term is a word that was found in dictionaries, a head word of an article.
Default: FALSE.

sect3.title: Net Dict
sect3.para: &app; may look up words in network dictionaries using a custom &app; network protocol. This configuration page allows you to register an account, select a server to use, and specify other related parameters.

listitem.para: Enables to use network dictionaries. You need to specify the dictionaries to use in the Manage Dictionaries dialog if you enable this option.
Default: TRUE.

sect3.title: Web browser
sect3.para: &app; may need to open a web link to start Internet search, show &app; home page, show a web page to download new dictionaries, new version of the application and for other reasons. This configuration page allows to specify how a web link should be opened.

listitem.para: This option allows you to specify a command to use for opening URLs. Some editions of &app; use platform-specific services for opening URLs by default. To use the custom command you need to check the checkbox below. For other editions of &app; the custom command is the only way to open a web link.
You may specify a program name (with or without full path) accompaned with any options required. The URL to open will be appended to this command at run time.
Default: firefox (depends on edition).

term.guilabel: Always use this command for opening URLs.

listitem.para: This option is only available in editions of &app; that can use other ways to open a web link.
Check this option to use the custom command to open web links instead of platform-specific services.
Default: FALSE.

When this option is checked, &app; search for the word you are typing in the search field automatically. &app; monitors key-press events, it starts searching the word entered as soon as there is no activity for more than a specified amount of time. The time span can be changed in the field below.
When this option is not checked, you need to press Enter in order for &app; to start searching the word.
Default: TRUE
A word change timeout in milliseconds. See the option above for details.
Default: 300 ms

term.guilabel: Show the first word when not found.

listitem.para: When &app; is unable to find the exact word requested, the application may propose another word that is close to the original. When this option is checked, the closest word will be shown in the definition area, otherwise, &app; tells that the original word is not found. Note, that this option applies to simple queries only, that is the queries that do not use regular expressions, patterns, fuzzy matchs and so on.
Default: TRUE

Allows to customize graphical appearance of the application. Select the Default item to restore the original appearance of &app;, no skins applied. You need to restart the application in order for changes to take effect. For instructions on how to prepare a custom skin see the doc/Skins file in &app; sources.
Default: Default.

term.guilabel: Hide main window when starting StarDict.

listitem.para: Controls whether the main window appears when you first start the program. If you select this option, you will only see an icon in the notification area after starting &app;. You may still get to the main window by clicking on this icon.
Default: FALSE.
This option enable the open main window hotkey, and allows to change that hotkey. When enabled, when user presses the hotkey, the main window is presented to the user.
Default: TRUE.
Default hotkey: CtrlAltz

Allows to make the main window transparent. Moving the slider you may change transparency degree. Transparency is measured in percents, it can range from 0 to 80, where 0 — fully opaque, 80 — almost fully transparent. Moving the slider has an immediate effect on the window.
On X11 this has any effect only on X screens with a compositing manager running. On Windows it should work always.
Default: 0 — fully opaque.

sect3.title: Search website
sect3.para: &app; may use Web search engines, Web dictionaries, databases providing web-based interface and other web sites providing information by request. The text to search is incorporated into URL. Normally, the text is assigned to a GET request parameter. For example, to search for word stardict in Google search engine you may use the following URL http://www.google.com/search?q=stardict. You can search the websites in &app; right-clicking the Internet search button in the main window.
&app; does not handle the web request itself, it only composes a URL and invokes an external program like a web browser or use platform-specific services to open the URL.

On this page you may see a list of web site. Use Add and Remove buttons to add new sites and remove existing records. Use Up and Down arrow buttons to reorder records in the list. Each record consists of three items:

listitem.para: This is a label you see in menu. Use a meaningful name.
Link to the main page of the website. This link is opened when there is nothing to search for, the search field is empty.
Link to perform request. %s identifies the place where to insert the search text. For example, http://www.google.com/search?q=%s.

term.guilabel: When middle mouse button is clicked:

listitem.para: Specifies an action to perform when user clicks the middle mouse button on the notification area icon. There are the following choices:

In the Do nothing case &app; simply ignores middle button clicks, otherwise &app; get text of the current selection, search for it and displays the results either in a floating window or in the main window.

In case there are a number of windows on desktop having text selected, there might be a confusion what text will be used. &app; works with the X Primary selection. Only one application can own a selection at a time, so when you select something in an application that application becomes the selection owner, the previous owner loses selection ownership. Now back to the question. &app; will use the text that was selected last.
Default: Query selection in floating window.

term.guilabel: Pronounce the word when it pops up.

listitem.para: When set, pronounce the word when the floating windows shows translation.
Default: FALSE.

term.guilabel: Show floating window if word not found.

listitem.para: This option allows to configure what to do if the word to be shown in the floating window is not found. You have two choices: 1) do not show the floating window at all — this option is unset, 2) show the floating window with text indicating that the word was not found — this option is set.
Default: TRUE.
Sets the floating window's max width.
Default: 320.
Sets the floating window's max height.
Default: 240.
Enables to use custom color for background in the floating window and select that color.
Default: FALSE.

Allows to make the floating window transparent. Moving the slider you may change transparency degree. Transparency is measured in percents, it can range from 0 to 80, where 0 — fully opaque, 80 — almost fully transparent. Moving the slider has an immediate effect on the window.
On X11 this has any effect only on X screens with a compositing manager running. On Windows it should work always.
Default: 0 — fully opaque.

sect1.title: Dictionary Management
sect1.para: To manage the dictionaries, click the Manage dictionaries button at the bottom-right corner of the main window, or click the Main menu button and choose Dict manage.
In the dictionary management dialog, you can disable dictionaries that you don't need, and you can set the order in which the dictonaries are queried.
&app; will search the dictionary files at "~/.stardict/dic" and "/usr/share/stardict/dic", and search tree dictionary files at "~/.stardict/treedict" and "/usr/share/stardict/treedict"

sect1.title: Related Projects
sect1.para: &app; would not be possible without many other projects' contributions. Here is a short list of projects that helped &app;.

sect2.title: StarDict 1.31
sect2.para: The original Motif/LessTif-based StarDict 1.31 written in 1999. &app; 2 got many good ideas from StarDict1.31 such as "Scan selection." Many of &app; 2's features, like "Fuzzy query," come from StarDict1.31.

sect2.title: StarDict 1.33+
sect2.para: StarDict1.33+ is a big enhancement of StarDict1.31. It added many dictionaries, and so it made me realize that dictionary data was not a barrier to a new, GTK2-based dictionary program. If there had been no StarDict1.33+, I would not have started the &app; 2 project. The author also helped me to port the StarDict 1.3 dictionary data files to &app; 2.

sect2.title: The DICT Project
sect2.para: Many dictd dictionaries have been ported to &app;. dictzip, which came from dictd, is also used by &app;.
To find more information about the DICT Project, please visit www.dict.org.

sect2.title: *Quick
sect2.para: Many wquick dictionaries have been ported to &app;.
To find more information about *Quick, please visit *Quick.

sect2.title: The Blowfish Project
sect2.para: The Blowfish Project provided the Oxford English-Chinese dictionary.
To find more information about the Blowfish Project, please visit the Blowfish Project Web site.

sect2.title: XDICT
sect2.para: XDICT's dictionary has been ported to &app;.

sect2.title: cdict5
sect2.para: cdict5's dictionary has been ported to &app;.

sect3.title: cdict5 v1.3
sect3.para: To find more information about the cdict5 Project, please visit the cdict5 on freshports.

sect2.title: CEDICT
sect2.para: CEDICT's dictionary has been ported to &app;.
To find more information about the CEDICT Project, please visit the CEDICT Project Web site.

sect2.title: CFFD
sect2.para: &app;'s icon was created with this software. CFFD also provided some useful information to me.
To find more information about the CFFD Project, please visit the CFFD Project Web site.

sect1.para: To find more information about &app;, please visit the StarDict Web site.
